bankData.pertinentInformation:
The deets:

Barclays are the biggest fossil fuel investors in Europe.

Banking on a Low Carbon Future (2020) have established that Barclays are taking negligible steps towards meeting their own, Paris-aligned, environmental policies.

Their commitment to divestment appears weak at best.

In 2022, the 4 other largest banks in the UK all made at least *some* level of commitment against providing funding for new oil and gas projects. Barclays is yet to follow suit.
bankData.summary:
Fossil Fuel Investments 2021: £15.5 billion

Barclays are Europe's #1 financiers of the fossil fuel industry.

Barclays are a big investor in Exxon Mobil - one of the largest fossil fuel companies, with a history of Indigenous Rights violations.
bankData.overallInvestmentTrendFossilFuels: negative: Barclays has reduced fossil fuel investment by just under $10bn between 2020/2021, and have reduced their investment by $12bn when compared to 2016. Every year since 2016 has seen a reduction in fossil fuel investment EXCEPT from 18/19 which saw an increase of ~$4bn.

bankData.pertinentInformation:
The deets:

Halifax is owned by The Lloyds Banking Group - one of the biggest investors of fossil fuels in the world. Many of Lloyd's subsidiaries have no commitment to divestment from fossil fuels.

However, according to Banking on a Low Carbon Future (2020) the group overall are around 61% of the way towards meeting their internal, Paris-aligned, climate strategy.

In 2022, Lloyds committed to rule out future investments in *new* oil, gas, and coal projects going forward. While this was a step in the right direction, project financing represents only a fraction of Lloyds' extensive fossil fuel investments, and the commitment does nothing to address their current investment portfolio. The bank remains an enormous investor in fossil fuel exploration, extraction, expansion, and infrastructure.
bankData.summary:
Fossil Fuel Investments 2021: £1.1 billion (Lloyds)

Many of Lloyd's subsidiaries have no commitment to divestment from fossil fuels.
bankData.overallInvestmentTrendFossilFuels: negative: Lloyds has an overall negative trend in fossil fuel investment - halving their investment from $2.6bn in 2016 to $1.3bn in 2021. Each year between has seen a gradual reduction, EXCEPT 2020 which saw an $800m INCREASE in fossil fuel investment.

bankData.pertinentInformation:
The deets:

HSBC are the third largest investors of fossil fuels in Europe; and second largest in the UK.

They are taking some, very slow, steps towards meeting their Paris-aligned climate-related policies.

In December 2022, HSBC committed to rule out future financing of ****new**** oil and gas fields. While this was a step in the right direction, oil and gas project financing represents only a fraction of HSBC's extensive fossil fuel investments, and the commitment does nothing to address their current investment portfolio. The bank remains an enormous investor in fossil fuel exploration, extraction, and infrastructure; including having ownership stakes in companies which have fossil fuel expansion plans.

Recently, even HSBC's so-called 'sustainable investments' were found to be funding destructive activities; including oil rigs, deforestation, and pipelines.
bankData.summary:
Fossil Fuel Investments 2021: £14.6 billion

HSBC are Europe's #1 financiers of fossil fuel expansion.

HSBC fund the Adani Group, whose fossil fuel projects are renowned for violating Indigenous Rights.
bankData.overallInvestmentTrendFossilFuels: neutral: HSBC invested ~$18bn in 1016 and ~$18bn in 2021. They frequently exceeded $20bn in the intervening years. The lack of pattern suggests either climate-sensitive goals are not set, or not taken seriously.

bankData.pertinentInformation:
The deets:

Santander are amongst the biggest fossil fuel investors in the world.

They have taken negligible steps towards meeting their own Paris-aligned climate strategy, suggesting they don't take environmental concerns seriously. Santander have made no commitment to phase **out** fossil fuel financing from their investment portfolio. While other big UK banks made commitments against future financing for *new* fossil fuel projects from 2022, Santander has fallen behind, having only made such a commitment for new oil project financing. Santander's current plans to be 'Net Zero' by 2050 include pumping money into fossil fuel companies in 2050 and beyond.
bankData.summary:
Fossil Fuel Investments 2021: £6.4 billion

Santander invests in Petrobras - a Brazilian oil company operating in the Amazon, which threatens Indigenous Peoples.

Santander have ****increased**** their investments in Arctic oil & gas, fracking, and LNG since the Paris Agreement.
bankData.overallInvestmentTrendFossilFuels: increase: Santander increased their investment in fossil fuel companies every year since 2016 with the single exception of 2021 (which saw an decrease compared to 2020 ($10.1bn), but still an increase when compared to 2016 ($6.5bn)).

bankData.pertinentInformation:
The deets:

NatWest are a major financer to the fossil fuel industry. While they invest less than some of the other big banks, they remain one of the biggest investors of fossil fuels in the world.

Don't be fooled by NatWest's role as 'principle partner of COP26. Despite partnering with an individual carbon footprint calculator to track their customers' emissions, the banks ***own*** climate impact is nothing to boast about. The bank has no commitment to phase **out** their fossil fuel investment; their goal to halve their financed emissions by 2030 is both too weak and and too delayed. Even if this target is met, NatWest will remain an enormous investor in fossil fuel exploration, extraction, expansion, and infrastructure; investments which are not compatible with a 1.5 degree pathway.
bankData.summary:
Fossil Fuel Investments 2021: £1.5 billion

NatWest have *********increased********* their investments in offshore oil & gas, and LNG since the Paris Agreement.

NatWest invest in tar sands oil - one of the most harmful fossil fuels for the planet.
bankData.overallInvestmentTrendFossilFuels: neutral: While The NatWest Banking Group have reduced their overall investment from $3.5bn (2016) to $1.8bn (2021), there has been negligible change in total investments over the past three years ($1.47bn (2019), $1.98bn (2020), $1.83bn (2021)). Despite initial momentum in 2016, this seems to have stagnated.

bankData.pertinentInformation:
The deets:

It's debunking time.

While the Co-operative Bank do not invest money in the fossil fuel industry, and frequently use ethical language when marketing their business, they do not qualify as one of our recommended providers.

The bank itself meets our criteria for investment/divestment commitments, however, these commitments can be considered a form of greenwashing as the fossil fuel industry is continually profiting from the bank's success.

The Co-operative Group no-longer own the Co-operative Bank. Since 2020, The Co-operative Bank has been owned by various asset management companies, including hedge funds with strong links to fossil fuels. More success for the bank means more profits for the fossil fuel industry. The bank needs to identify and remove all links to the fossil fuel industry in order to regain their status as an ethical bank.

bankData.pertinentInformation:
The deets:

Starling Bank are co-founders of an industry initiative called TechZero - designed to measure and help reduce tech companies' impact on the climate. They have also stated that they will not invest in, or take money from, the fossil fuel (or fossil fuel-related) industry.

After some controversy (both internal and external) regarding the bank accepting funds from the Qatari Investment Authority (connected to the country's oil reserves), Starling committed to finding and phasing-out all environmentally harmful investments.

This project has since been completed, demonstrating that Starling take their climate commitments seriously.

After a thorough assessment of Starling's commitments and investments we are confident in Starling's environmental credentials.
